Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Coppice woodland
Description: Coppicing is a traditional woodland management technique, used to harvest the young, fast-growing stems of particular tree species (e.g., hazel). Repeatedly fell trees at the base and allow them to regrow for a number of years.

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Thin trees within forests
Description: Selective removal of trees to reduce tree density & improve growth of remaining trees. Benefits biodiversity by removing some of the canopy.

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Manage woodland edges for maximum habitat heterogeneity
Description: Butterflies and catepillars often have different habitat requirements but poor dispersall. Edges provide open habitat and when have more varied structure - create vriation by felling, encouraging scrub growth or 'scalloping' to increase the length of the edge.

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Manage heathland by cutting
Description: Clearing small areas at appropriate times of year to introduce heterogeneity.

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Restore or create peatland
Description: Raise the water table to rewet the surface peat, and create a hydrological buffer zone by rewetting the area that surrounds the peatland. Raising the water table can be done through blocking drainage ditches, planting flood-resistant vegetation, blocking channels, building raised embankments to retain water, inserting damsbelow the peat surface, switching off drainage pumps, felling trees or restoring inflows.

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Manage wetlands or ponds by grazing or cutting to prevent succession
Description: Wetlands require disturbance to prevent succession into scrub or woodland. Cutting or mowing wetlands, or grazing with domestic livestock to replace natural disturbance regimes. Timing is important.

Broad_Action: Create pockets of new habitat throughout the site

Description: Set-aside can be roatational (in a different place every year or two or non-rotational (same place for 5-20 years), fields can be sown with fallow crops or left to naturally generate.

Broad_Action: Restore hedgerows around the site to improve ecological connectivity
Method: Plant new or maintain existing hedgerows on farmland
Description: Maintain and manage hedgerows in a biodiversity friendly approach to provide resources and transport corridors for mammals

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Plant trees on farmland
Description: Plant trees across farmland to introduce heterogeneity and provide undisturbed habitat

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Exclude livestock from semi-natural habtiat
Description: Prevent livestock from grazing semi-natural habitats such as by fencing off areas

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Reduce intensity of grazing by domestic livestock
Description: Reduce the number of livestock grazing on the land, lower stocking density

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Use livestock fences that are permeable to wildlife
Description: Fences for livestock or wild herbivores can act as barriers to non-target species - ensure fences have gaps for small mammals to move through

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Restore former mining sites
Description: Restoration of former mining sites usually involves establishing native plants, with the aim of reducing erosion or concentration of pollutants

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Install tunnels/culverts/underpass under roads
Description: There are purpose-built wildlife tunnes, culverts that assist with drainage can also be used by wildlife. Ledges can be places on the sides of culverts so that animals can pass through (as some animals won't use a culvert due to water at the base).

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Retain/maintain road verges as small mammal habitat
Description: Roadside verges that are maintained without pesticides, reduced mowing etc. can provide habitat for small mammals

Broad_Action: Manage existing water features (ponds, lakes, rivers) in a biodiversity-friendly manner
Method: Provide mammals with escape routes from water features
Description: Mammals may struggle to get out if the fall in or enter a water feature. Include ramps, ladders, shallow inlets, gentle side slopes so that mammals can get out.

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Use selective harvesting instead of clearcutting
Description: By not clearcutting you retain some habtiat for mammals to still use.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Retain understorey vegetation within plantations
Description: Retain the understorey when planting as it can provide resources for mammals.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Gather coarse woody debris into piles after felling
Description: Coarse woody debris consists of fallen dead trees and cut branches that are left during tree harvesting. Gathering into piles as a single point or  a line across the forest floor can increase structural diversity

Broad_Action: Create habitat corridors between existing habitats
Method: Retain wildlife corridors in logged areas
Description: Leave corridors of natural unharvested vegetation for mammals to travel along in felled areas

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Harvest timber outside mammal reproduction period
Description: Plan timber harvesting when young are at their most vulnerable as to reduce direct casualties of felling operations

Broad_Action: Minimise the use of chemical pesticides, insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, rodenticides, etc. on site
Method: Reduce pesticide or fertiliser use
Description: Reduce use as chemicals can have effects directly or indirectly on mammal populations.

Broad_Action: Create habitat corridors between existing habitats
Method: Create or maintain corridors between habitat patches
Description: Ensure corridors are available between same habtiat types so animals can disperse between.

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Provide artificial refuges/breeding sites
Description: Provide artificial dens or nesting boxes around the site in suitable habitats

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Provide artificial refuges/breeding sites
Description: Provide artificial dens or nesting boxes around the site in suitable habitats

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Reduce stocking density of livestock on peatlands
Description: If there are signs of trampling, grazing is too high and grazing level should be reduced. Grazing a bog with appropriately low numbers and types of stock/herbivores, tall heathre, shrubs, and rushes will be lightly browsed, which will keep light penetration to the moss layer, allowing Sphagnum growth. See https://www.nature.scot/doc/peatland-action-peatland-management-guidance-grazing-and-muirburn for stocking density guidelines.

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Restore artificial drains
Description: Raise the water table, create shallow pools and allow excess water to seep out of the pools across the peatland. Many options including peat dams, plastic piling dams, composite dams, wooden, metal or stone dams, drain reprofiling in combination with drain blocking, wave dams, zipping. Proper technical guidance should be followed and the technique used should be based on peat depth, depth of the drains, slope, accessibility and other factors of the site. Advice can be found at: https://www.nature.scot/doc/peatland-action-technical-compendium-restoration-4-artificial-drains

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Use bunding techniques to stop subsurface flow and water loss from an area, or to stop flow of water to reduce water loss and erosion.
Description: Many techniques available for raised bog, such as deep bunding, used for cracks and pipes in deep layers of pear or hold rainflow and slow lateral movement of water, methods incl. trench bunding or back-filled trenches. Surface nunding is used where there is a need to impede and/or distrupt surface flow over bare peat, methods include cell bunding, fish=scale or scallop bunding, finger tie backs, gully bunds/blocking. Seek technical advice at: https://www.nature.scot/doc/peatland-action-technical-compendium-restoration-5-bunding-intervention

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Slow the flow of water through gully and bare peat restoration. Methods include using surface bunds in gullies. For very deep gullies with high flows of water stone dams can be used.
Description: The surface bund method uses surface bunds to slow the flow of water through a gully, and can facilitate revegetation. Material for bunds can be site-specific. Stone dams are used when erosion is down to the mineral layer, or where peat is less than 50 cm deep. See https://www.nature.scot/doc/peatland-action-technical-compendium-restoration-6-flow-management for best practice.

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Stablilise and revegetate gullies and bare peat, as actively eroding and exposed bare peat is inhospitable for plants to grow, many methods can be used to restore bare peat to more stable condition and to restore peat-forming habitats.
Description: Methods include reprofiling hags, gullies or peat banks; Mulching to re-vegetate gullies, peat pans and micro-erosion; textile application to revegetate gullies, peat pans and micro-erosion; whole turving; reinstate borrow pits and donor turf sites; transplant propagules; use nurse grass seeds mixed with peatland species seeds or mulch. For advice see: https://www.nature.scot/doc/peatland-action-technical-compendium-restoration-7-stabilisation-and-revegetation

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Harvest trees on peatland
Description: Recover as much timber as possible. Follow advice from: https://www.nature.scot/doc/peatland-action-technical-compendium-restoration-8-forest-bog-restoration

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Block furrows that were created during forestry activities in order to raise the water table and stop erosion.
Description: Can be done similar to drain blocking and drain reprofiling, or can use timber trunks and brash left over from tree felling. Follow advice from: https://www.nature.scot/doc/peatland-action-technical-compendium-restoration-8-forest-bog-restoration

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Smooth the ground to remove ridges and furrows on previously afforested sites and to create a flatter topography similar to near natural peatlands.
Description: This can include stump flippings, furrow reprofiling following furrow blocking, and cross-tracking. Follow advice from: https://www.nature.scot/doc/peatland-action-technical-compendium-restoration-8-forest-bog-restoration

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Remove scrub to return peatland to an open habitat.
Description: Methods of scrub removal depend on the level of scrub, i.e., light, intermediate, and heavy. For definitions and methods: https://www.nature.scot/doc/peatland-action-technical-compendium-restoration-9-scrub-removal

Broad_Action: Create habitat corridors between existing habitats
Method: Ensure connectivity between habitat patches
Description: Retain or creat corridors between forest patches

Broad_Action: Create habitat corridors between existing habitats
Method: Provide or retain un-harvested buffer strips
Description: Wider buffer strips provide corridors and resources for birds in woodland habitats in areas where trees are being felled.

Broad_Action: Encourage farmers to engage with biodiversity-friendly management
Method: Increase the proportion of natural/semi-natural vegetation in the farmed landscape.
Description: Increase the natural vegetation within farmland, through hedgerow management, reducing management interventionson field margins and road verges, Hare's Corner etc.

Broad_Action: Encourage farmers to engage with biodiversity-friendly management
Method: Pay farmers to cover the costs of conservation.
Description: Similar to Agri-Environment Schemes that have shown success in inputting conservation measures into argricultural environments.

Broad_Action: Encourage farmers to engage with biodiversity-friendly management
Method: Provide or retain set-aside areas on farmland
Description: Set aside areas can be sown with fallow crops or left to naturally regenerate and they can be rotational or long-term.

Broad_Action: Manage hedgerows in a biodiversity-friendly manner
Method: Manage hedgerows to benefit wildlife
Description: Reduce cutting frequency, reduce or avoid spraying, mowing vegetation beneath hedgerows and fill gaps in hedgerows.

Broad_Action: Restore hedgerows around the site to improve ecological connectivity
Method: Plant new hedges
Description: Plant new hedgerows connecting habitats, following appropriate guidelines

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Manage ditches to benefit wildlife
Description: Managing ditches involes delaying cutting of vegetation on ditch banks and restrcited fertiliser, herbicide or pesticide use on ditch banks or in field adjoining ditches.

Broad_Action: Encourage farmers to engage with biodiversity-friendly management
Method: Protect in-field trees
Description: Retain in-field trees and developing agro-forestry systems

Broad_Action: Create pockets of new habitat throughout the site
Method: Plant wild seed or cover mixture
Description: Plants that provide seed food for wild birds include maize, sunflower and cereals, which can be planted in blocks or 6 m wide strips or juveniles and are sometimes called wild bird cover, 'game crops' or 'game cover crops'.

Broad_Action: Create pockets of new habitat throughout the site
Method: Plant nectar flower mixture/wildlife strips
Description: Flowering plants are sown in strips or blocks, for bees and other flower-visting insects. Nectar flower mixture can include agricultural varieties of flowering plants such as clovers

Broad_Action: Create pockets of new habitat throughout the site
Method: Create uncultivated margins around intensive arable or pasture fields
Description: Allow field margin vegetation to regenerate naturally, not fertilised and reduce cutting, although it can involve subsequent mowing.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Use mowing techniques to reduce chick mortality
Description: Use wildlife-friendly mowing techniques, such as beginning mowing in the middle of fields outwards so that nesting  birds can escape to field margins

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Provide refuges in fields during harvest or mowing
Description: During mowing and harvesting operations, leaving unharvested refuges provides ground-nesting birds and their chicks a better chance of survival

Broad_Action: Create pockets of new habitat throughout the site
Method: Take field corners out of management
Description: Field corners can be taken out of management on both arable and livestock farms - e.g., Hare's Corner

Broad_Action: Encourage farmers to engage with biodiversity-friendly management
Method: Increase crop diversity across a farm or farmed landscape
Description: Increasing the range of different crops grown in a given year may increase the biological value of a farm by increasing farmland heterogeneity

Broad_Action: Encourage farmers to engage with biodiversity-friendly management
Method: Undersow spring cereals, with clover (ex.)
Description: Undersow cereals with plants such as clover which fix nitrogen and reduce the need to apply fertiliser - while also providing food resources for invertebrates

Broad_Action: Encourage farmers to engage with biodiversity-friendly management
Method: Plant more than one crop per field (intercropping)
Description: Planting more than one crop in each field increases habitat heterogeneity at a smaller scale than increasing crop diversity at a landscape scale.

Broad_Action: Encourage farmers to engage with biodiversity-friendly management
Method: Reduce tillage
Description: Conventional ploughing can damage soil structure and potentially reduce the abundance of soil invertebrates. This intervention can include layered cultivation, non-inversion tillage and conservation tillage.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Create skylark plots
Description: Skylarks require short vegetation to nest in and skylark plots are small (usually 4-16m2) undrilled patches within cereal fields that provide this with little impact on overall yield.

Broad_Action: Create pockets of new habitat throughout the site
Method: Create beetle banks
Description: Beetle banks are grassy mounds, about 2 m wide that run across the middle of large arable fields. They provide habitat for predatory insects that could provide foraging habitats for birds

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Maintain species-rich, semi-natural grassland
Description: Low-intensity management of grasslands has produced some of the most species-rich habitats. This includes attempting to replicate traditional management.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Reduce management intensity on permanent grasslands
Description: This can involve reducing or stopping the use of fertilisers, herbicides, and pesticides; delaying the mowing date; reducing the number of cuttings taken.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Reduce grazing intensity
Description: Reducing the grazing intensity may reduce the damage to vegetation and can also help reduce disturbance to birds and accidental loss of nests

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Provide short grass for waders
Description: Retain smaller areas for waders where there are requirements for wader habitats

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Raise mowing height on grasslands
Description: High vegetation can provide more complex environments and more habitats but cut short vegetation can allow birds access to the ground which can help foraging, and can reduce the risk of predation.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Delay mowing or first grazing date on grasslands
Description: Early season mowing can cause death of young chicks of ground-nesting birds, delaying mowing until after chicks can escape is therefore a part of many agri-environment schemes.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Leave uncut rye grass in silage fields
Description: Rye grass, Lolium perenne, seeds are a potential food source, but cutting rye grass fields multiple times a year for silage removes seed heads before they can ripen and so reduces the food available to birds the following winter. Leaving fields or plots uncut may therefore provide valuable overwinter food.

Broad_Action: Encourage farmers to engage with biodiversity-friendly management
Method: Plant cereals for whole crop silage
Description: Cereal-based wholecrop silage (CBWCS) is an intervention that involves growing crops, not grass, to turn into silage. This may provide seed resources for grain-eating farmland birds throughout the year.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Maintain upland heath
Description: Upland heath is maintained though enclosed grazing. This intervention includes grazing on acid grassland, dry and wet upland heath

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Thin trees within forests
Description: Selective removal of trees to reduce tree density & improve growth of remaining trees. Benefits biodiversity by removing some of the canopy.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Coppice woodland
Description: Coppicing is a traditional woodland management technique, used to harvest the young, fast-growing stems of particular tree species (e.g., hazel). Repeatedly fell trees at the base and allow them to regrow for a number of years.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Manage woodland edges for birds
Description: Manage woodland edges in a biodiversity-friendly way

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Change timing of building work
Description: Building work should be avoided at times of year when they are most vulnerable, such as during hibernation and the maternity season

Broad_Action: Create habitat corridors between existing habitats
Method: Create or restore bat foraging habitat in urban areas
Description: Providing foraging habitat for bats in urban areas may reduce the impact of residential and commercial development - existing foraging sites may be protected or replaced with suitable alternatives. Could be done off-site within the local community for WFs.

Broad_Action: Encourage farmers to engage with biodiversity-friendly management
Method: Engage farmers and landowners to manage land for bats
Description: Land outside of turbines, landowners could be engaged so that they manage their land in ways that help maintain bat populations. This may be done by providing advice and support to farmers on how to manage their land specifically for bats.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Provide or retain set-aside areas in farmland
Description: Allocation of some fields taken out of production was compulsory under European Agricultural Policy from 1992 until 2008

Broad_Action: Create habitat corridors between existing habitats
Method: Reduce field size (or maintain small fields)
Description: Reducing field size or maintaining small field sizes increases field boundaries and field margins, increasing the density of linear features (hedgerows). But this would need to be away from the turbines.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Retain unmown field margins
Description: Field margins can provide foraging habitat for bats by increasing invertebrate prey. This would need to be away from turbines and alongside flight paths (linear features)

Broad_Action: Manage hedgerows in a biodiversity-friendly manner
Method: Manage hedges to benefit bats
Description: Bats prefer taller, wider, structurally diverse hedgerows and those with emergent trees. Reducing the cutting frequency and retaining trees, minimising pesticides and filling gaps are likely to benefit. Would need to be on site perimeter away from turbines.

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Retain remnant forest or woodland on agricultural land
Description: Remnant woodland fragments may be important for bats in agricultural landscapes. Need to be sufficiently away from turbines or flight paths that lead to turbines

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Retain riparian buffer stips on agricultural land
Description: Retain buffers of woodland, forest or other vegetation along streams and rivers

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Apply a textured coating to turbines
Description: Applying a textured coating could reduce bat collisions as bats approach textured surfaces less often than smooth surfaces - mixed results.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Deter bats from turbines using ultraound
Description: Broadcasting ultrasonic sounds at the frequency range which bats use for echolocation may act as a deterrent by interfering with their ability to perceive echos.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Retain a buffer between turbines and habitat features used by bats
Description: Leave a minimum distance between wind turbines and bat roosts or habitat features to create a buffer zone. The EUROBAT guidance on wind turbines and bats recommends a mimum distance of 200 m between wind turbines and important bat habitats. Natural England, UK recommends a minimum distance of 50m from the turbine blade tip and the nearest bat habitat feature. [BCI guidance to be released 2024]

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Prevent turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds ('feathering')
Description: Feathering is when wind turbine blades are prevented from turning when they are not operational which may protect bat species. Often done in combination with increased cut-in speed

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Slow rotation of turbines at low wind speeds
Description: Slowing the rotation of turbine blades below the cut-in speed may reduce bat fatalities which are higher at low wind speeds. Feathering preferred but this works as an alternative.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Increase the wind speed at which turbines become operational ('cut-in speed')
Description: Cut-in speed at which the turbine begins to generate electricity and the blades can move at a maximum rotation speed. Increasing turbine cut-in speeds (known as 'curtailment') may reduce bat fatalities).

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Automatically reduce turbine blade rotation when bat activity is high
Description: Involves the use of automatic bat registration systems to monitor bat activity and shut down operation of wind turbines when bat activity reaches a predetermined 'high' level.

Broad_Action: Create pockets of new habitat throughout the site
Method: Restore bat foraging habitat at ex-quarry sites
Description: Abandoned mining sites, such as quarries, may be rehabilitated to provide foraging habitat for bats, e.g., through the restoration of grassland, trees, and wetlands.

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Thin trees within forests
Description: Selective removal of trees to reduce tree density & improve growth of remaining trees. Benefits biodiversity by removing some of the canopy.

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Use selective or reduced impact loggining instead of conventional logging
Description: Selective removal of trees to reduce tree density & improve growth of remaining trees. Benefits biodiversity by removing some of the canopy. Trees are removed based on the diameter, height, or species. Remaining trees are left in the stand, as opposed to clearcutting where all trees are felled.

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Use shelterwood cutting instead of clearcutting
Description: The process involves selective removal of the overstorey trees to allow enough light through the forest floor to create new, even-aged stands below. The remaining mature overstorey trees provide seeds for regeneration and create shelter for the younger trees.

Broad_Action: Create habitat corridors between existing habitats
Method: Retain forested corridors in logged areas
Description: Retain corridors of unlogged mature forest within logged areas. This may provide foraging and roosting opportunities for bats and maintain connectivity in disturbed landscapes.

Broad_Action: Manage in a biodiversity-friendly way - creating space for biodiversity
Method: Retain riparian buffers in logged areas
Description: Retain unlogged buffers along streams and rivers in logged areas. This may provide foraging and roosting opportunities for bats and maintain connectivity in disturbed landscapes.

Broad_Action: Minimise the use of chemical pesticides, insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, rodenticides, etc. on site
Method: Reduce pesticide, herbicide or fertiliser use
Description: These may degrade bat foraging habitats and reduce the availability of prey. Exposure to contaminants may not only kill bats but also can have serious sub-lethal effects.

Broad_Action: Minimise the use of chemical pesticides, insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, rodenticides, etc. on site
Method: Prevent pollution from agricultural land or forestry from entering watercourses

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Use low intensity lighting
Description: Dimming lights, or using low wattage or low insensity lights

Broad_Action: Create pockets of new habitat throughout the site
Method: Increase the proportion of natural/semi-natural vegetation in the farmed landscape.
Description: Protect or create field-margins, ditch banks, hedgerows, woods and ponds

Broad_Action: Create pockets of new habitat throughout the site
Method: Provide or retain set-aside areas in farmland
Description: Set aside can be rotational (in a different place every year or two) or non-roational (same place for 5-20 years) and the fields can either be own with fallow crops or left to naturally regenerate. Set-aside is not ploughed or harrowed except for the purpose of sowing. Set aside can be managed by cutting or can have strips of wildflower or grasses sown in.

Broad_Action: Create habitat corridors between existing habitats
Method: Connect areas of natural or semi-natural habitat
Description: Create habitat corridors between currently isolated natural/semi-natural habitats or the restoration of natural/semi-natural habitats between existing patches.

Broad_Action: Manage hedgerows in a biodiversity-friendly manner
Method: Manage hedgerows to benefit wildlife
Description: Involves reducing the cuting frequency, reducing or avoiding spraying, mowing vegetation beneath hedgerows, fill gaps in hedges, coppice or lay to restore traditional hedge structure.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Manage ditches to benefit wildlife
Description: Reduce mowing and grazing regimes and by ditch management practices including cleaning/dredging technique, season and frequency.

Broad_Action: Create habitat corridors between existing habitats
Method: Plant new hedges
Description: Plant hedges/hedgerows

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Plant wild seed or cover mixture
Description: Wild bird cover crops are often planted in blocks or 6m wide strips and left unharvested.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Plant nectar flower mixture/wildlife strips
Description: Flowering plants are sown in strips or blocks, for bees and other flower-visting insects. Nectar flower mixture can include agricultural varieties of flowering plants such as clovers

Broad_Action: Create habitat corridors between existing habitats
Method: Create uncultivated margins around intensive arable or pasture fields
Description: Allow the field margin vegetation to regenerate naturally without planting, but it can involve subsequent mowing. Field margins are not fertilised and only spot-treated with herbicides if injurious weeds occur.

Broad_Action: Implement nature-based solutions around the site
Method: Plant grass buffer strips/margins around arable or pasture fields
Description: This involves plantng field margins with a grass-rich seed mixture. It includes floristically-enhanced grass margins. The margins are not fertilised.

Broad_Action: Manage areas in a pollinator-friendly manner and report to the AIPP
Method: Provide nest boxes for bees (solitary bees or bumblebees)
Description: Solitary bee species nest either in cavities such as hollow stems or bored holes in wood or masonary, or in the ground. Solitary bee nest boxes typically consist of common reed stems or options incl. wood or paper tubes. Success depends on nest box design, siting and availability of foraging resources.

Broad_Action: Implement nature-based solutions around the site
Method: Increase crop diversity across a farm or farmed landscape
Description: Increasing the range of different crops grown in a given year may increase the biological value of a farm by increasing farmland heterogeneity

Broad_Action: Create pockets of new habitat throughout the site
Method: Take field corners out of management
Description: Field corners can be taken out of management on both arable and livestock farms - e.g., Hare's Corner

Broad_Action: Create nesting or food resources for pollinators/invertebrates
Method: Create beetle banks
Description: Grassy mounts about 2m wide that run across the middle of large arable fields. They may be created using two-directional ploughing and sown with a mix of grass species.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Plant crops in spring rather than autumn
Description: Planting crops in spring rather than autumn can be better for autumn

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Undersow spring cereals, with clover (ex.)
Description: Sow grass or clover beneath a cereal crop, the undersown crop is later ploughed in

Broad_Action: Create pockets of new habitat throughout the site
Method: Convert or revert arable land to permanent grassland
Description: Change from an arable crop to a sown agricultural grassland, to be used for grazing or silage.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Reduce tillage
Description: Various methods to reduce the depth or intensity of ploughing, such as layered cultivation, non-inversion tillage and conservation tillage. It also includes stopping tillage altogether in some places.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Maintain species-rich, semi-natural grassland
Description: This involves altered mowing or grazing regimes and reduced inputs or while some studies also tested the effectiveness of mulching or burning.

Broad_Action: Identify opportunities to restore habitats
Method: Restore or create species-rich semi-natural grassland
Description: Measures used to restore or create grasslands of high plantdiversity such as chalk grasslands and hay meadows include grazing, mowing, sowing, and hay spreading.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Add yellow rattle seed (Rhinanthus minor) to hay meadows
Description: Yellow rattle is an annual wildflower that parasitises other plants, particularly grasses, allowing other wildflower species to establish

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Raise mowing height on grasslands
Description: High vegetation can provide more complex environments and more habitats but cut short vegetation can allow birds access to the ground which can help foraging, and can reduce the risk of predation.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Delay mowing or first grazing date on grasslands
Description: Delay the first cut (until later in the summer) and little agrochemical use

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Reduce grazing intensity on grassland by seasonal removal of livestock
Description: Reduce livestock grazing intensity on peermanent grassland (including seaosnal removal of livestock).

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Maintain upland heath/moorland
Description: Use management techniques to maintain the conservation value of uplant heath or moorland, including enclosed rough grazing. Treatments include, removing or reducing grazing, controlling dominance of grass species by cutting or grazing by goats, and carryout out grouse moor management (roatational burning combined with predator control).

Broad_Action: Identify opportunities to restore habitats
Method: Restore or create upland heath/moorland
Description: Upland heath/moorland typically consists of dwarf shrubs such as heather. Moorland can become dominated by scrub or grasses such as purple moor grass.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Exclude livestock from semi-natural habtiat
Description: Prevent livestock from grazing semi-natural habitats such as by fencing off areas

Broad_Action: Implement nature-based solutions around the site
Method: Provide buffer strips alongside water courses (rivers and streams)
Description: Uncultivated strips at the edge of waterways help reduce diffuse pollution from agricultural systems

Broad_Action: Minimise the use of chemical pesticides, insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, rodenticides, etc. on site
Method: Reduce chemical inputs in grassland management
Description: Reduce the amount of chemical inputs applied to permanent grasslands or cease inputs altogether. Chemical inputs to permanent grassland may include fertilisers such as nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P) or potassium (K).

Broad_Action: Minimise the use of chemical pesticides, insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, rodenticides, etc. on site
Method: Use organic rather than mineral fertilisers.
Description: Organic fertilisers such as farmyear manure (incl. green manure or crop residues), slurry and other composts provide an alternative to synthetic or mineral fertilisers).

Broad_Action: Implement nature-based solutions around the site
Method: Create scrapes and pools
Description: Creating scrapes and pools in wetlands and wet grasslands can help create a heterogenous habitat with varying vegetation types and water levels. Scrapes consist of pools or strips of shallow water which dry during the summer.

Broad_Action: Remove invasive species from the site, adhering to correct removal methods to reduce risk of spread
Method: Control invasive non-native plants on farmland (such as Himalayan balsam, Japanese knotweed).
Description: Techniques to control species involve a range of methods including mechanical control such as cutting or cultivation.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Control scrub
Description: If scrub dominates non-productive land on farms it may lead to declides in species that require grassland and other farmland habitats. Scrub control may include cutting, grazing, or herbicide application.

Broad_Action: Remove invasive species from the site, adhering to correct removal methods to reduce risk of spread
Method: Control grey squirrels
Description: Grey squirrels may cause damage to woodlands through bark stripping and competing with the native red squirrel, and carrying squirrel pox virus.

Broad_Action: Remove invasive species from the site, adhering to correct removal methods to reduce risk of spread
Method: Control mink
Description: Mink can have a significant effect on local wildlife. This intervention may involve controlling mink populations through trapping.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Manage wild deer numbers
Description: Wild deer populations can cause damage to woodlands, crops and other wildlife habitats through browsing and bark stripping. Management of deer is required to prevent damage to native habitats.

Broad_Action: Minimise the use of chemical pesticides, insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, rodenticides, etc. on site
Method: Do nothing or do less
Description: Don't replace the use of herbicides. Look strategically at where vegetation can be left alone or where expectations can be adjusted. Look at if there is an actual need to spray an area.
Source: Alternatives to herbicides. A guide for the amenity sector.

Broad_Action: Minimise the use of chemical pesticides, insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, rodenticides, etc. on site
Method: Manage with mechanical methods
Description: Methods include hand-weeding, mowing or strimming, mulching, planting regimes.
Source: Alternatives to herbicides. A guide for the amenity sector.

Broad_Action: Minimise the use of chemical pesticides, insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, rodenticides, etc. on site
Method: Design out the need for herbicides
Description: Better design could reduce or remove the need to use herbicides.
Source: Alternatives to herbicides. A guide for the amenity sector.

Broad_Action: Minimise the use of chemical pesticides, insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, rodenticides, etc. on site
Method: Thermal control with hot water or foam
Description: Steam, hot water, and hot water with foam added. The root is not immediately killed but would require repeated treatments the plant will eventually weaken and die down its roots. Hot water system uses water heated to 120 degrees which is applies with a low pressure system with a long hose - effective at killing weeds and can be used for other purposes such as killing moss and algae. The hot foam system is similar but includes a foam from vegetable oils to hold the water at a high temperature for longer. This makes it more effective at killing the plant. Machinery availability a limitation [1 supplier in Ireland at the moment].
Source: Alternatives to herbicides. A guide for the amenity sector.

Broad_Action: Minimise the use of chemical pesticides, insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, rodenticides, etc. on site
Method: Brushing
Description: Brushing can be very effective to control weeds on pavements, gravel, block paving and other hard surfaces. Wire brushes are spun at high speed over the surface of the ground to rip weeds over the ground.
Source: Alternatives to herbicides. A guide for the amenity sector.

Broad_Action: Remove invasive species from the site, adhering to correct removal methods to reduce risk of spread
Method: Japanese knotweed control using mesh
Description: This forces the plant to server its  own stems as it grows against the mesh. A fine mesh is placed on the ground where the knotweed is growing.
Source: Alternatives to herbicides. A guide for the amenity sector.

Broad_Action: Remove invasive species from the site, adhering to correct removal methods to reduce risk of spread
Method: Stem inject japanese knotweed or giant hogweed with herbicide. This is very effective but poses a slight risk of run off into the environment.
Source: Alternatives to herbicides. A guide for the amenity sector.

Broad_Action: Develop a plan for monitoring and managing invasive species
Method: Adopt a pesticide-free policy
Description: Undertake an audit of current pesticide/herbicide use across all sectors including. Initiate a stakeholder forum for land managers. Develop a communications strategy for trialling non-chemical weed control methods in a variety of locations.
Source: Alternatives to herbicides. A guide for the amenity sector.

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Peat dams
Description: Wide track machine 12 feet wide with load bearing pressure <2psi or no more than 1.6 lb inch-2. 30 per dam installed. 1m deep, 50 cm above bog surface and 50 cm wider than drain width of 1-2 m. Using machine and peat.

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Plastic dams
Description: Installed by hand, 90 per dam installed, 1m deep, <1m wide. Corrugated sheets of 5mm HDPE* interlocking piling 25cm wide.

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Partial infilling of drain
Description: Done by hand, 15 per linear metre using local peat infill, variable length, 1m deep 1m wide, requires humified peat.

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Tree clearance
Description: Site preparation for drain blocking. Chainsaw crew of three and thumb and grab machine to remove cut trees. 1,200 per day. Clear material away from drains and acess routes

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Removal of conifer plantation
Description: Clear felling using specialist harvester machine or chain saw. Harvester costs 1200-1500 per ha. Chainsaw 900-1200 per ha.

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Barrier dam
Description: Installed with a machine. 25-30 per linear metre. Tench 1.5 m deep and 0.5m wide, filled with peat. Finished height 1m above bog surface and convered with living bog vegetation or scaw. Materials include humified peat and machine.

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Weir
Description: Constructed from 8x4' steel sheet, 6mm thick, seams welded. Finished structure coated in galvanised. 3,500. Materials include an 8x4' steel sheet, 6mm thick.

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Sphagnum transfer inoculation
Description: Done by hand, 1,325 per ha. Hectare of bare peat inoculated. Materials needed include live Sphagnummoss from a donor site and straw.

Broad_Action: Create/Improve pond habitats
Method: Create new pond habitats.
Description: Full guidance see The Irish Pond Manual. Initial steps incl. Legal check (if planning is required), decide what the main, and secondary uses of the pond will be, identify a site (ensure availbility of unpolluted water), make sure thesite has no existing wildlife or archaeological interest, check that the project is not constrained by services, prepare a design for the pond, dig trial holes, plan the pond stages.
Source: A Guide to the Creation and Management of Ponds

Broad_Action: Create/Improve pond habitats
Method: Create a pond complex
Description: Pond complexes are better than one single large pond. A pond complex includes small seasonal ponds, large deep pond, shallow pond and large deep ponds.
Source: A Guide to the Creation and Management of Ponds

Broad_Action: Remove invasive species from the site, adhering to correct removal methods to reduce risk of spread
Method: Monitor and remove invasive species from ponds
Description: See A Guide to the Creation and Management of Ponds for a full description of plants that are non-native to Irish ponds.
Source: A Guide to the Creation and Management of Ponds

Broad_Action: Create/Improve pond habitats
Method: Avoid planting ponds up wherever possible.
Description: Species will often find their own way to the pond. If planting is necessary for aesthetic reasons see guidance in 'A Guide to the Creation and Management of Ponds'
Source: A Guide to the Creation and Management of Ponds

Broad_Action: Restore hedgerows around the site to improve ecological connectivity
Method: Plant hedgerows
Description: Drainage should be considered, a bank or ditch may be desirable. Leave sufficient width for the established hedge (2m), young plants should be closely spaced (50cm max) and should be planted on a herringbone/zigzag line, not a straight line. If possible, linking up with existing hedges to provide the most effective wildlife corridor. Use good quality, native plants, already represented in hedgerows in the area. Crann can advice on locally sourced plants. New growth must be protected from weed competition until it's established. Young hedgerows must be protected from browsing by livestock fences at least 1m away from the hedge on each site. The young plants will need some clipping to encourage a good shape.

Broad_Action: Manage hedgerows in a biodiversity-friendly manner
Method: Cut hedgerows in a friendly manner.
Description: Hedges should be cut while they are dormant from the beginning of September to the end of Februaru. Hedges should be cut in an A-shaped profile, with a busy top for maximum protection from the wind. Overgrown hedges may be restored by coppicing selective cutting at ground level to promote bushy regrowth.

Broad_Action: Manage hedgerows in a biodiversity-friendly manner
Method: Close gaps in hedgerows
Description: Hedge-laying involves part cutting through of selected stems, bending them over at an angle of 70-80 degrees and securing the stems. This is recommended for hedge rejuvenation and stockproofing. Gaps in hedgerows that cannot be closed by laying should be planted with hawthorn quicks, blackthorn or other suitable native species at not more than 30cm spacing in prepared ground. The young plants should be cut back to half their height after planting to promote growth.

Broad_Action: Manage hedgerows in a biodiversity-friendly manner
Method: Do not apply herbicides, pesticides or fertilisers
Description: Within 1.5 m of a hedgerow as this leads to nutrient enrichment that can advaasrely affect biodiversity

Broad_Action: Manage hedgerows in a biodiversity-friendly manner
Method: Fencing wire must not be attached to hedgerow trees and shrubs
Description: Avoid placing fencing wire on trees or shrubs within the hedgerow.

Broad_Action: Manage hedgerows in a biodiversity-friendly manner
Method: Manage hedge trimmings
Description: Hedge trimmings should be piled in a non-intrusive manner to provide habitat. If hedge trimmings are to be removed or burned, this must be done immediately after cutting.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Maintenance/retention of forest cover.
Description: Continuous cover forestry, where a canopy is maintained throughout the lifetime of commercial forests, with ongoing and small scale harvesting of individual trees and groups of trees should be practiced more widely in Ireland. Where this is not possible or practical, patches of mature trees retained after clearfelling may serve as resevoirs for such species, ensuring that they do not go entirely extinct on the site.
Source: ForestBIO: Management of biodiversity in a range of forest types.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Species: Birds, epiphytes, ground vegetation, ground-dwelling invertebrates
Method: Diversity of age structure.
Description: In areas being managed by clearfelling, staggering harvesting of large, contiguous blocks so that a mosaic of widely different age classes develops will maximise the diversity of forest blocks
Source: ForestBIO: Management of biodiversity in a range of forest types.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Species: Birds, epiphytes, ground vegetation, ground-dwelling invertebrates
Method: Diversity of vegetation structure
Description: The structural requirements of different species and groups are diverse, so providing a wide range of vegetation structures within a stand will tend to maximise the number of species it can support.
Source: ForestBIO: Management of biodiversity in a range of forest types.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Species: Birds, epiphytes, ground vegetation, ground-dwelling invertebrates
Method: Native broadleaved species
Description: Diversity and abundance of broadleaved species in the canopy, understorey and shrub layer, whether derived from planted stock or from natural regeneration were found to benefit several taxa.
Source: ForestBIO: Management of biodiversity in a range of forest types.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Species: Birds, Lower trunk epiphytes, ground vegetation
Method: Grazing management
Description: In highly grazed forests, increasing light penetration will not be enough to ensure establishment of native trees and shubs, and an increase in field layer cover.
Source: ForestBIO: Management of biodiversity in a range of forest types.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Proximity to old woodland and conversion to native species
Description: Where plantations have been established on or in close proximity to historical or existing areas of old woodland, this may provide an increased chance for some forest specialists with limited distributions or poor abilities to colonise.
Source: ForestBIO: Management of biodiversity in a range of forest types.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Deadwood
Description: Deadwood is important for many forest species, particularly non-vascular plants and fungi which use it as a substrate. The positive effect of deadwood on ground vegetation depends to a large extent on this resource being available in conjunction with optimal light level so measures to increase availability of deadwood should try to ensure that it is provided in a range of conditions from light-exposed to shaded.
Source: ForestBIO: Management of biodiversity in a range of forest types.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Nest sites
Description: In plantations lacking ecologicallt mature (i.e., commercially over-mature) or standing dead trees, lack of nest sites for hole-nesting birds can be addressed in the short term by providing nest boxes, longer term by letting over mature trees be retained.
Source: ForestBIO: Management of biodiversity in a range of forest types.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Native species
Description: Mixes planted for biodiversity should, wherever possible, include at least one native tree species.
Source: ForestBIO: Management of biodiversity in a range of forest types.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Ecological compatibility
Description: If mixes are to be used as part of a biodiversity enhancement strategy, they should be comprised of species that are compatible with one another to increase the chance of the native element successfully exerting an influence on the commercial conifer element.
Source: ForestBIO: Management of biodiversity in a range of forest types.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Favour native element
Description: Wherever the native element of a mix is at a competitive disadvantage to the more commercial element, mixes should be managed to prevent the native element being excluded from the canopy and eventually shaded out altogether. Such management might incorporate strategies such as strategic thinning around native trees, aggregating planting of natives to reduce competition with surrounding commercial species.
Source: ForestBIO: Management of biodiversity in a range of forest types.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Species: Birds, epiphytes, ground vegetation, ground-dwelling invertebrates
Method: Grazing and vegetation structure
Description: Because light is a much less limiting factor in native woodlands than in plantations, grazing is likely to be even more important in terms of the influence it has on understorey canopy, shrubs and other vegetation layers. Heavy grazing may limit the development of understorey vegetation but in the open canopy of native woodlands, one or more understore vegetation layers may become dominant.
Source: ForestBIO: Management of biodiversity in a range of forest types.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Deadwood
Description: This has been found to be one of the most important factors influencing temperate forest biodiversity, with more forest specialist species depending on deadwood than any other forest-related resource. Most native woodlands have very depleted deadwood resources compared to long-established forests in Europe. Management to improve deadwood resources should aim to increase the abundance and diversity of deadwood, particularly of large diameter classes of deadwood in a variety of decay states.
Source: ForestBIO: Management of biodiversity in a range of forest types.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Species: Birds, epiphytes, ground vegetation and invertebrates
Method: Conservation and restoration of native woodland
Description: All native woodland patches should be considered potentially worth of conservation, regardless of their size. Wherever possible existing native woodlands should be extended and, where appropriate, improved. Conversion and modification of existing plantations to become more similar in composition and character to native woodlands will also enhance Ireland's forest biodiversity.
Source: ForestBIO: Management of biodiversity in a range of forest types.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Native woodland diversity
Description: They found that the species assemblages supported by ash and oak dominated woodlands were different for several taxa. In order to ensure the effective conservation of native woodland biodiversity in Ireland, all types of woodland native to Ireland should be conserved and especially for rarer woodland types, extended.
Source: ForestBIO: Management of biodiversity in a range of forest types.

Broad_Action: Manage areas in a pollinator-friendly manner and report to the AIPP
Method: Provide butterfly-friendly foodplant plants
Description: Grow ivy which is an autumn food source for butterflies,
Source: Gardening for Butterflies - The National Biodiversity Data Centre

Broad_Action: Manage areas in a pollinator-friendly manner and report to the AIPP
Method: Provide caterpillar food plants
Description: Plant certain plant speceis depending on which butterflies are local to the area - info on what species can be found where, and their preferred catipillar foodplant on the NBDC
Source: Gardening for Butterflies - The National Biodiversity Data Centre

Broad_Action: Manage areas in a pollinator-friendly manner and report to the AIPP
Method: Leave areas of Nettles to grow wide
Description: Nettles are one of the most popular plants for caterpillars and many species feed on them. The Peacock, Red Admiral, Comma, Painted Lady and Small Tortoiseshell all feed on Nettle during the caterpillar stage. Around 18 moth species also feed on nettle in Ireland. Nettles may need to be cut back, and caterpillars prefer to feed on new growth.
Source: Gardening for Butterflies - The National Biodiversity Data Centre

Broad_Action: Manage areas in a pollinator-friendly manner and report to the AIPP
Method: Allow other species of grass to grow.
Description: There are many species of butterflies in Ireland that feed on grasses during the caterpillar stage, but over-relying on one species, or a narrow range of grasses, will limit butterflies. Meadow Brown, Ringlet, Small Heath, and Speckled Wood all feed on grasses. Perennial Rye Grass provides limited to no support for biodiversity - so should be avoided.
Source: Gardening for Butterflies - The National Biodiversity Data Centre

Broad_Action: Manage areas in a pollinator-friendly manner and report to the AIPP
Method: Provide roosting habitats for butterflies
Description: Butterflies roost on the understide of leaves, in long grass, rock crevices or similar shelted places.
Source: Gardening for Butterflies - The National Biodiversity Data Centre

Broad_Action: Manage areas in a pollinator-friendly manner and report to the AIPP
Method: Provide overwintering habitats for butterflies
Description: The majority of butterflies will overwinter in the caterpillar stage. Habitats needed for butterflies overwintering in one of their immature stages are: leaf litter, thick/uncut vegetation, log piles.
Source: Gardening for Butterflies - The National Biodiversity Data Centre

Broad_Action: Manage areas in a pollinator-friendly manner and report to the AIPP
Method: Leave an area of uncut grass all year round.
Description: Uncut grass provides shelter for butterflies in diapause and pupating and food for caterpillars that feed on grass.
Source: Gardening for Butterflies - The National Biodiversity Data Centre

Broad_Action: Manage areas in a pollinator-friendly manner and report to the AIPP
Method: Create a short-flowering meadow.
Description: Cut and lift every 4-6 weeks starting in mid-April. When cutting at the end of September, leave some patches uncut as they will provide refuge for caterpillars and eggs.
Source: Gardening for Butterflies - The National Biodiversity Data Centre

Broad_Action: Manage areas in a pollinator-friendly manner and report to the AIPP
Method: Create a long-flowering meadow.
Description: Cut once a year in September, giving wildflowers a chance to drop their seeds in August. This can take a few years to fully establish and can look a bit messy at times, but over time as the soil fertility reduces, a rich variety of plants will appear. When cutting at the end of September, leave some patches uncut as they will provide refuge for caterpillars and eggs.
Source: Gardening for Butterflies - The National Biodiversity Data Centre

Broad_Action: Manage areas in a pollinator-friendly manner and report to the AIPP
Method: Manage hedgerows for butterflies
Description: Irish hedgerow species are preferred, including hawthorn, blackthorn, buckthorn, holly & ivy. Multiple species hedgerows are preferred. Long, overhanging flowering hawthron hedges, with a mixture of trees and ivy are wonderful for biodiversity. Cut hedgerows as little as possible. Allow hedgerows to grow as tall as possible.
Source: Gardening for Butterflies - The National Biodiversity Data Centre

Broad_Action: Manage areas in a pollinator-friendly manner and report to the AIPP
Method: Allow plants to grow on walls and fences to provide resources for butterflies
Description: Native species that can be trained to a wall or fence that will encourage butterflies in your garden, including dog rose, ivy, honeysuckle (only Lonicera periclymenum is native to Ireland).
Source: Gardening for Butterflies - The National Biodiversity Data Centre

Broad_Action: Minimise the use of chemical pesticides, insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, rodenticides, etc. on site
Method: Encourage aphid predators.
Description: Encourage aphid predators such as ladybirds, ground beetles, hoverflies, and earwigs by managing in a biodiversity-friendly way.
Source: Gardening for Butterflies - The National Biodiversity Data Centre

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Increase the extent of scrub communities, through natural regeneration, planting and layering, and protection from browsing.
Description: Natural regeneration uses a ready source of regeneration seed - and is the best means of expanding scrub communities. If seeding cannot occur, planting or layering may be needed to regenerate stands, especially for rare species and communities. The presence of high density of grazing or browsing animals, domestic or wild, is likely to limit scrub establishment and grazing pressure would need to be reduced by either reducing livestock densities, fencing or tree guards.
Source: The Scrub Management Handbook: Guidance on the management of scrub on nature conservation sites.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Improve the quality and maintain scrub communities
Description: Allow some browsign or grazing to create or maintain structural mosaics, but excessive or insufficient grazing pressure can damage the interest.Coppicing, cutting the scrub to encourage regeneration from the stump maintains and enhances the scrub stand. Thinning or selective removal of individual stems or shrubs, reduces the density of scrub stands, creates dappled light conditions and with regeneration in the gaps creates a fine-scale structural diversity, Mowing is an alternative to browsing or burning. Periodic use of controlled burning on flammable scrub species, creates and maintains mosaics of open habitat with scrub. The interface between scrub and other habitats is important, a diverse long interface provides shelter and a variety of aspects, optimising microhabitat provision, interfaces can be maintained using grazing, mowing or flails. Decaying wood is important for invertebrates and fungi, standing dead wood and can be created by ring barking, a proportion of retained logs or tightly stacked brash may be beneficial. As a component of the structural mosaic of scrub stands, bare earth is important for invertebrates and pioneer plants, it can be created and maintained during scrub management.
Source: The Scrub Management Handbook: Guidance on the management of scrub on nature conservation sites.

Broad_Action: Identify opportunities to restore habitats
Method: Reduce the extent of scrub
Description: Water level management, inundating stanking scrub kills some species. Weeding, by hand pulling seedlings is slow but prevents unwanted scrub from establishing and is more cost effective and less disruptive than removing shrubs when they have grown bigger. Cutting operations will require follow up treatment to prevent re-growth from stumps. A large volunteer labour resource is effectie with light tools, mechanised cutting with chainsaws or clearing saws suits larger stands. Manual stump removal is slow, grinders will destroy stumps in situ with minimal soil disturbance. Diggers provide a faster work rate and can be used on larger root plates but will produce more ground disturbance and materials for disposal.
Source: The Scrub Management Handbook: Guidance on the management of scrub on nature conservation sites.

Broad_Action: Identify opportunities to restore habitats
Method: Eradicating scrub
Description: Cutting off at ground will be needed for well-grown stands, all cutting will require follow-up treatment to prevent re-growth from the stump or seeds. Stump removal can be manual or use grinders. Grubbing out using 30 excavators or bulldozers - can be cost effectively cleared mechanically.
Source: The Scrub Management Handbook: Guidance on the management of scrub on nature conservation sites.

Broad_Action: Manage existing water features (ponds, lakes, rivers) in a biodiversity-friendly manner
Method: Manage scrub in proximity to ponds and other water features.
Description: Encroachment of scrub around ponds is likely to limit their value for a range of amphibians.However, maintaining pioneer scrub with a diverse structure near ponds and on other habtiats can benefit both amphibians and reptiles as it provides shelter and a rich source of invertebrate food.
Source: The Scrub Management Handbook: Guidance on the management of scrub on nature conservation sites.

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Maintain a 50 m buffer from habitat features (hedgerows, treelines, etc.)
Description: 50 m buffer from habitat features is often a planning requirement but this buffer should be maintained at throughout the operational life of the windfarm
Source: NIEA - Guidance on Bat Surveys, Assessment & Mitigation for Onshore Wind Turbine Developments

Method: Maintain a 200 m buffer around semi-natural woodlands.
Description: 200 m buffer from habitat features is often a planning requirement but this buffer should be maintained at throughout the operational life of the windfarm
Source: NIEA - Guidance on Bat Surveys, Assessment & Mitigation for Onshore Wind Turbine Developments

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Maintain a 100 m buffer between the turbines and the edge of the forestry.
Description: 100 m buffer from commercial forestry edge is often a planning requirement but this buffer should be maintained at throughout the operational life of the windfarm
Source: NIEA - Guidance on Bat Surveys, Assessment & Mitigation for Onshore Wind Turbine Developments

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Feather the turbine blades
Description: The turbine blades are pitched at 90 degrees or parallel to the wind to reduce their rotation speed while idling to below two revolutions per minute.
Source: NIEA - Guidance on Bat Surveys, Assessment & Mitigation for Onshore Wind Turbine Developments

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Curtail the turbines
Description: Curtailment involves raising the cut-in speed of wind turbines and feathering the blades to reducetheir operation during periods of high bat activity. Curtailment can be applied as a blanket aproach during certain times of the year when bats are most active (usually April to October) or it can be linked to real time data, e.g., temperature and wind speed, gathered on site and programmed using the SCADA operating system of wind turbines.
Source: NIEA - Guidance on Bat Surveys, Assessment & Mitigation for Onshore Wind Turbine Developments

Broad_Action: Manage in a positive way for native species
Method: Use post-construction monitoring
Description: Post construction monitoring should be carried out on all sites where a curtailment regime has been implemented. Where post construction monitoring is recommended it should be detailed in a Bat Monitoring and Mitigation Plan (BMMP) which should be submitted for assessment and agreed before any planning approval is granted. Post construction monitoring should last for a period of 3-5 years depending on the risk level of the site but should also be subject to review.
Source: NIEA - Guidance on Bat Surveys, Assessment & Mitigation for Onshore Wind Turbine Developments

Broad_Action: Restore and rehabilitate peatland habitats
Method: Convert commercial forest on peat soils to bog
Description: Remove trees by enhanced felling (removing the whole tree). Brash removal is then conducted to limit nutrient input. Reprofile the site, most commonly done by 'cross track' - where a low pressure trached vehicle(s) is driven over the ridges to flatten them into furrows. Tree stumps will also need to be delt with - stump flipping is commonly used on former Sitka spruce plantations on deeper peat deposits, where an excavator is used to flip the stump and root plate out of the ridge and into the furrow. On shallower peats and former lodgepole pine plantations stump auguring can be used, which drills the stump into smaller pieces.
Source: IUCN Peatland Programme: Forest to bog restoration, demonstrating success.
